body: For the moment I'm really confused by the change to _low_test.py. The test was written to have client-side and server-side be independent, the way they would be if they were running across the network from one another. By sharing a completion queue that design intention of the test goes totally out the window. What am I not yet understanding?

I think that the test as originally written tries to pretend that client
and server can inhabit the same thread. The change I'm making to C core
eliminates a background thread that kept this working by moving associated
work into the completion queue (I may yet rename some apis as part of this
work).

There are two correct ways to refactor the python test here:
1. Merge the completion queues. This holds most of the test flow as it was,
and is what I've included here.
2. Split the client and server parts into separate threads. This makes it
very difficult to reason about the ordering of events as you do in this
test.

The third way is to continue to imagine schemes whereby c core does this
threading itself. I have a suspicion that at least some of the flakiness
we've seen is due to internal core thread counts being undersized. One way
to fix that is to give the core ample threads for all use cases: this leads
to infinite thread requirements. The other way is to engineer such that
those threads are no longer required.

I should also note that I think (1) above is the better choice for Python.
Whilst slightly more synthetic than it was, it gives a simple to understand
acid test of wrapped primitives. It will likely break if primitives are
broken, and it's simplicity will ensure that it doesn't become a
maintenance burden.

Fixes #52
Fixes #51
Starting to do the final bits of work here.

Need to fix another instance of #1635 in the completion queue implementation.
Also need to test ssl.

At the moment I actually find (2) more attractive. _low_test is intended to validate and illustrate full end-to-end behavior with both invocation and service sides of RPCs. Having them share a completion queue still undermines that aspect of the test. Use of threads doesn't, I don't think, and inserting "do X in a separate thread" in several places throughout the test doesn't interrupt the overall flow of the test, at least not if the off-threading is moved out into a well-abstracted helper function?

Another high-level, philosophical question about this change: if _low_test.py has to change in this pull request because of changes to the semantics to the C Core's completion queue semantics, shouldn't this pull request include a change to grpc.h? It doesn't at the moment, right, unless my browser's find-in-page is broken?

Oh, and to respond directly to "This makes it very difficult to reason about the ordering of events as you do in this test.": I would not want _low_test to lose the reasoning about the ordering of events that it has today. If something has to be done in another thread, it's very easy to write it as

offthread = threading.Thread((thing that must be done in another thread))
offthread.start()
offthread.join()

and retain deterministic ordering of the RPC operations under test, correct?

Philosophy note: this PR is still in progress, so documentation is probably
lacking. That said I'm not certain that it's changing semantics from what
we've had for a long while, rather it's exploiting loopholes that have been
deliberately left open to allow this sort of thing. I'll make a lawyer pass
over grpc.h before this is finalized regardless.

With your proposed rewrite you would still end up needing two threads
polling completion_queue_next for things to work out.... meaning that at
every point where you do:

self.server_completion_queue.get(_FUTURE);

You'd also need a thread doing:

self.client_completion_queue.get(XXX);

and asserting that such a thread receives nothing in the period of time
that the server_completion_queue took to get something - in other words,
both threads would need some barrier logic at every completion queue poll
in order to keep the logic in the test as-is. I don't see a way to make
that readable - but if it's preferred, I'd be happy to review proposals.

For an example of what this would need to transform into, take a look at my
changes to src/ruby/spec/client_server_spec.rb - it's the (mostly)
equivalent test for Ruby, and was written in such a way that spinning up
multiple threads was the obvious and simple thing to do.

Finally, in the version of _low_test.py I've proposed the testing of ordering
of events is preserved in all cases except the terminal event handling on
line 378 of the original test - and I would argue is strengthened, as the
new phrasing of the test additionally guarantees that no event is received
by the peer completion queue at a particular step.

For those following along at home: @ctiller and I just talked this over, and the point of misunderstanding between us comes from this work making a big change to the semantics of calls and completion queues.  Without this change, a call sequence like

call.write(data)
write_done_indication = completion_queue.next()

has semantics of "request that work be done in the first call, understand that work may be done between calls, and then at some arbitrary later time ask for acknowledgement of the work having been done". With this change, the same call sequence has semantics of "describe some work to be done in the first call, understand that it may not be done between calls, and then in the second call do the work if it has not by chance or larger circumstance already had occasion to happen". With this change work like "transmit bytes on the wire" is no longer guaranteed to happen with call.write alone; the call to completion_queue.next is now required to ensure that transmission of data on the wire takes place.

We spoke of possibly changing Core API function names to reflect these different behaviors.
@nicolasnoble @yang-g @vjpai @dgquintas - we should talk about code review strategy.
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle - I think this is ready for the new low_test.py
@jtattermusch - can you merge in the latest C# changes?

I have updated _intermediary_low_test to work with these changes in https://github.com/nathanielmanistaatgoogle/grpc/commit/eb717991623eee892e28bf21663ee557006a5b7b. Please feel encouraged to rewrite/rebase the commit; there's no reason why it should be in a separate commit from _low_test (or any other Python changes).

Is it possible to send me a pull request against #1577?

I have several kloc of work across various branches based upon this pull
request, and have no intention of rebasing all of them, so this commit
structure is now immutable.

@dgquintas, @nicolasnoble - please do the review (break it up among yourselves). I'm talking with @jtattermusch about getting #1731 in ahead of time (C# is a sticking point) in order to reduce the size of this review (as it includes that PR).

Green.
I've reviewed up to tcp_client.h (exclusive). I'll continue tonight.

With enough tests (about 3 failures out of 20000 total tests), I get a few for this branch that look like this:

D0618 10:07:56.987466586   26319 test_config.c:52] test slowdown: machine=1.000000 build=1.000000 total=1.000000
I0618 10:07:56.987597711   26319 cancel_after_invoke.c:57] test_cancel_after_invoke/chttp2/fullstack/cancel

FAILED: bins/opt/chttp2_fullstack_with_poll_cancel_after_invoke_unsecure_test [ret=-6, pid=26319]
Alright, I finished proof-reading this (my eyes are still a bit bleeding), and I didn't see anything out of whack.
LGTM!

I ran some iterations of C# tests against this and it looks like the returned status codes for some of the calls are still getting mixed up from time to time.
In unknown method handler tests, I sometimes receive "Unkown" status instead of "Unimplemented"
and in some other tests, I sometimes get "cancelled" instead of "unknown".

I ran with -n 100 ( = 300 suites in total) and got 15 failures.

Jan: OK with this going in and a quick follow-up being written tomorrow?
